title: India national cricket team

summary: The India national cricket team is also known as Team India and Men in Blue. India is ranked first in Tests, second in ODIs and second in T20Is by the ICC. Virat Kohli is the current captain of the team, while the head coach is Ravi Shastri.

value.label: The Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai has been host to numerous high-profile cricket matches in the past, most notable being the 2011 Cricket World Cup Final, in which India defeated Sri Lanka by 6 wickets. The stadium witnessed the last match of Sachin Tendulkar's international career.

The advent of One Day International (ODI) cricket in 1971 created a new dimension in the cricket world. India began as a weak team in ODIs and did not qualify for the second round in the first two editions of the Cricket World Cup. 

However, under the captaincy of Kapil Dev, India won the Cricket World Cup in 1983, defeating the favourites and the two-time defending champions West Indies in the final at Lords, owing to a strong bowling performance.

India and Pakistan jointly hosted the 1987 World Cup, the first time that the competition was held outside England. They again jointly hosted the 1996 World Cup with Sri Lanka. Sachin Tendulkar and Anil Kumble joined the national side in 1989 and 1990 and further improved the team. However, the team was damaged in 2000 when Mohammed Azharuddin and Ajay Jadeja were implicated in match fixing and given bans.

Since 2000, the Indian team underwent major improvements under the captaincy of Sourav Ganguly and guidance of John Wright, India's first foreign coach. It made it to the final of the 2003 World Cup, but failed to advance past the group stage of the 2007 World Cup.

Dravid stepped down as the captain of the team, following which Dhoni was made the captain of the Twenty20 and ODI team. In September 2007, India won the first-ever Twenty20 World Cup. India went on to win the 2011 Cricket World Cup. India then won the 2013 Champions trophy, thus making Dhoni the first captain in history to win the three major ICC trophies.
